p: Some controversies about taxonomic assignments in these studies remain unresolved. For instance, in 2010 Kamal-Eldin [ 95] reported the content of sesamin and sesamolin in S. latifolium as published in 1988 in a Japanese journal [ 72], but in the cited publication S. radiatum rather than S. latifolium was named. Kamal-Eldin [ 95] did not explain why she assumed that S. radiatum in this publication [ 72] was actually S. latifolium.
